case_name: Carona Sahu Co. Ltd. v. Sales Tax Officer

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 275 of 1964 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 275 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Bombay High Court judgment dated April 23, 1962 in Sales Tax Reference No. 18 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 23, 1962 of the Bombay High Court in Sales Tax Reference No. 18 of 1961.

facts.text: Appellant is a manufacturer of footwear in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a manufacturer of footwear in Bombay.

facts.text: During assessment year April 1, 1954 to March 31, 1955, appellant purchased rubber from dealers in State of Cochin.

anchor.surface_text: During the assessment year April 1, 1954 to March 31, 1955, the appellant purchased rubber from certain dealers residing in the State of Cochin.

facts.text: Purchases assessed to purchase tax by Sales Tax Officer under S. 10(a) of Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1953 as made from non-registered dealer.

anchor.surface_text: These purchases were assessed to purchase tax by the Sales Tax Officer under S. 1 0  a  of the Bombay Sales Tax Act  Bombay Act III of 1953-hereinafter referred to as the Act  as they were made from a person who is number a registered dealer.

facts.text: Cochin sellers had agents in Bombay who received orders on behalf of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Cochin sellers had their agents in Bombay who received orders on behalf of the appellant.

facts.text: Orders of appellant accepted by agents in Bombay and goods shipped by sellers from Cochin to Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The orders of the appellant were accepted by the agents in Bombay and the goods were shipped by the sellers from Cochin to Bombay.

facts.text: After shipment, demand drafts forwarded with Bills of Lading by vendors to bankers in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: After the goods were shipped, the demand drafts were forwarded along with the Bills of Lading by the vendors to their bankers in Bombay.

facts.text: Bankers endorsed Bill of Lading in Bombay and handed to purchasers in Bombay in exchange for price.

anchor.surface_text: The bankers endorsed the bill of lading in Bombay and handed it over to purchasers in Bombay in exchange for the price.

facts.text: Price paid in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The price was also paid in Bombay.

facts.text: In Bills of Lading, sellers in Cochin described as both consignors and consignees.

anchor.surface_text: In the Bills of Lading the sellers in, Cochin were described as both companysignors and companysignees.

facts.text: Invoice stated: Shipped per S.S. from Cochin to Bombay on account and risk of Messrs Carona Sahu Co. Ltd., 15-A, Elphinstone Circle, Fort, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: After the goods were shipped, an invoice was drawn on the appellant in which were printed the following words Shipped per S.S from Cochin to Bombay on account and risk of Messrs Carona Sahu Co. Ltd., 15-A, Elphinstone Circle, Fort, Bombay.

facts.text: Appellant assessed to purchase tax by Sales Tax Officer, Licence Circle, Bombay by order dated March 31, 1956 under cl. (a) of s. 10.

anchor.surface_text: For the period April 1, 1954 to March 31, 1955, the appellant was assessed to purchase tax by the Sales Tax Officer, Licence Circle, Bombay by his assessment order dated March 31, 1956, under cl.  a  of s. 10 of the Act

facts.text: Appellant appealed under s. 30 to Assistant Collector of Sales Tax, Appeals 11, Bombay Circle, appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant preferred an appeal under s. 30 of the Act to the Assistant Collector of Sales Tax, Appeals 11, Bombay Circle, Bombay but it was dismissed.

facts.text: Revision to Additional Collector of Sales Tax dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: A revision application to the Additional Collector of Sales Tax was dismissed.

facts.text: Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal dismissed revision on September 4, 1959 and confirmed orders of Sales Tax authorities.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated September 4, 1959 the Bombay Sales Tax Tribunal dismissed the revision application and companyfirmed the order made by the Sales Tax authorities.

facts.text: Tribunal referred questions to Bombay High Court under s. 34(1).

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the appellant, the Sales Tax Tribunal referred the following questions of law for decision of the Bombay High Court under s. 34 1  of the Act

facts.text: Bombay High Court by judgment dated April 23, 1962 answered questions in favour of State against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated April-23, 1962 the Bombay High Court answered both the questions of law in favour of the State and against the appellant.

facts.text: Property in rubber consignments passed to appellant in Bombay, not Cochin.

anchor.surface_text: Applying this principle to the present case, we are of the opinion that the High Court rightly held, upon the facts found, that the property in the rubber companysignment passed to the appellant in the State of Bombay.

facts.text: Insurance charges borne by appellant, who paid freight and other charges.

anchor.surface_text: The insurance charges were borne by the appellant who also paid freight and other charges.

facts.text: Bills of lading sent by sellers through bank to be delivered to buyers in Bombay on payment of price.

anchor.surface_text: The bills of lading were sent by the sellers through the bank to be delivered to the buyers in Bombay on payment of the price of the goods.

facts.text: High Court held property intended to pass in Bombay; invoice endorsement meant insurance by buyers.

anchor.surface_text: In view of these facts, the High Court held that the property was intended by the parties to pass in Bombay and the endorsement in the invoice that the goods were being shipped on account of and at the risk of the buyers did number mean anything more than that the insurance charges were to be paid by the buyers.

facts.text: Appellant contended property passed in Cochin.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant, Mr. Donde submitted that the property in the rubber companysignments had passed to the appellant in Cochin.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no warrant for appellant's submission; High Court view correct.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is numberwarrant for this submission and the view taken by the High Court is companyrect.

facts.text: Cochin sellers not registered dealers under Bombay Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: as they were made from a person who is number a registered dealer. The Cochin sellers had their agents in Bombay

facts.text: Purchase tax under s.10(a) leviable on purchases from non-registered dealers.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of s. 10 a  of the Act are satisfied in the present case and the purchases in question accordingly are liable to tax.

facts.text: Appellant argued s.10(a) person means dealer in Bombay not registered.

anchor.surface_text: It is argued by Mr. Donde that the term person in s. 10 a  should be read as meaning a dealer who carries on business in Bombay but who is number registered under the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected appellant's argument on s.10(a) interpretation.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the argument put forward by Mr. Donde as companyrect.

facts.text: S.10-C does not apply as property passed inside Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: S. 10-C reproduces the Explanation to Art. 286 1  a  of the Constitution and it would apply where under general law the sale takes place outside the State

facts.text: Appellant argued s.10(a) not apply to inter-state purchases as s.10-C applies.

anchor.surface_text: The next companytention of Mr. Donde is that the provisions of S. 10 a  cannot apply to transactions of purchase where the purchased goods have been brought from outside

anchor.surface_text: Ss. 23 and 25 of the Indian Sale of Goods Act are identical in language to the corresponding provisions of the English Sale of Goods Act.

issues.text: whether, on the facts and circumstances of the case, the property in the rubber companysignments passed to the appellant in Cochin i.e. outside the territorial limits of the State of Bombay

anchor.surface_text: The first question that arises for determination in this case is, whether, on the facts and circumstances of the case, the property in the rubber companysignments passed to the appellant in Cochin i.e. outside the territorial limits of the State of Bombay. In this companynection the facts found by the Sales Tax Tribunal are that the Cochin sellers had their agents in Bombay who received the orders of the appellant and arranged for the shipping of the- goods.

issues.text: whether the purchase tax under S. 10 a  was leviable in respect of the purchases in dispute

anchor.surface_text: We pass on to companysider the second question of law arising in this case-whether the purchase tax under S. 10 a  was leviable in respect of the purchases in dispute. It is necessary at this stage to reproduce the relevant provisions of the Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1953 as it stood at the material time.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case, the property in the rubber companysignments passed to the applicant in Cochin i.e. outside the State of Bombay

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the appellant, the Sales Tax Tribunal referred the following questions of law for decision of the Bombay High Court under s. 34 1  of the Act Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case, the property in the rubber companysignments passed to the applicant in Cochin i.e. outside the State of Bombay ?

issues.text: Whether the purchase tax under s. 10 a  is leviable in respect of the purchases in dispute

anchor.surface_text: Whether the purchase tax under s. 10 a  is leviable in respect of the purchases in dispute ? By its judgment dated April-23, 1962 the Bombay High Court answered both the questions of law in favour of the State and against the appellant.

issues.text: whether the term person in s. 10 a  should be read as meaning a dealer who carries on business in Bombay but who is number registered under the Act

anchor.surface_text: It is argued by Mr. Donde that the term person in s. 10 a  should be read as meaning a dealer who carries on the business of selling or buying goods in the pre- Reorgansiation State of Bombay excluding the transferred territories,

issues.text: whether the provisions of S. 10 a  cannot apply to transactions of purchase where the purchased goods have been brought from outside the State of Bombay for companysumption in that State because s. 10-C of the Act would apply to such transactions

anchor.surface_text: The next companytention of Mr. Donde is that the provisions of S. 10 a  cannot apply to transactions of purchase where the purchased goods have been brought from outside the State of Bombay for companysumption in that State because s. 10-C of the Act would apply to such transactions.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant, Mr. Donde submitted that the property in the rubber consignments had passed to the appellant in Cochin.

arguments.court_reasoning: no warrant for submission; High Court view correct

arguments.claim: goods were shipped on account and at the risk of Messrs. Carona Sahu and Company P Ltd. and therefore the property in the goods must be held to have passed to the appellant on shipment in Cochin

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it was contended that the goods were shipped on account and at the risk of Messrs. Carona Sahu and Company P Ltd. and therefore the property in the goods must be held to have passed to the appellant on shipment in Cochin.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court rightly held upon facts found that property passed in Bombay

arguments.claim: Where goods are shipped and by the bill of lading the goods are deliverable to the order of the seller or his agent, the seller is prima facie deemed to reserve the right of disposal

anchor.surface_text: S. 25 states as follows Where there is a contract-for the sale of specific goods or where goods are subsequently appropriated to the contract, the seller may, by the terms of the contract or appropriation, reserve the right of disposal of the goods until certain conditions are fulfilled.

arguments.claim: delivery by the seller is not delivery to the buyer, but to the captain as bailee; bill of lading to seller's order controls possession and reserves property even with risk term

anchor.surface_text: Where goods are delivered on board a vessel to be carried, and a bill of lading is taken, the delivery by the seller is not delivery to the buyer, but to the captain as bailee for delivery to the person indicated by the bill of lading.

arguments.claim: in Gabarron v. Kreeft, appropriation not such as to pass property if no intention; bill of lading to seller's order prevents passing

anchor.surface_text: In Gabarron v. Kreeft 1 Lord Parker laid down the principle as follows The English cases, however, on which the Sale of Goods Act was founded seem to show that the appro- 1 1875 L.R. 10 Ex. 274. priation would not be such as to pass the property if it appears or can be inferred that there was no actual intention to pass it.

arguments.claim: in Shepherd v. Harrison, property did not pass despite invoice on account and risk of buyer because bill of lading reserved jus disponendi

anchor.surface_text: In Shepherd v. Harrison 1 the plaintiff in England sent an order to P and Co. at Pernambuco to buy cotton for the plaintiff. P and Co. bought cotton on account of the plaintiff and made out an invoice on account and risk of Ms. John Shepherd Co. 1 1871 L.R. V H.L. 116.

arguments.claim: the term person in s. 10 a should be read as meaning a dealer who carries on business in Bombay but who is not registered under the Act

anchor.surface_text: It is argued by Mr. Donde that the term person in s. 10 a should be read as meaning a dealer who carries on business in Bombay but who is not registered under the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: unable to accept; no reason for limitation on plain meaning of person

arguments.claim: purchases made by a dealer from a person who is not a registered dealer will be subject to purchase tax

anchor.surface_text: That section plainly states that purchases made by a dealer from a person who is not a registered dealer will be subject to purchase tax. The appellant is a dealer and it has made the purchases in question from the sellers who are not registered dealers.

anchor.surface_text: The next contention of Mr. Donde is that the provisions of S. 10 a cannot apply to transactions of purchase where the purchased goods have been brought from outside

arguments.claim: The provisions of s. 10 a of the Act are satisfied in the present case and the purchases in question accordingly are liable to tax

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of s. 10 a of the Act are satisfied in the present case and the purchases in question accordingly are liable to tax.

arguments.claim: scope and ambit of these two sections [s.10(a) and s.10-C] are different

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the scope and ambit of these two sections are different.

arguments.claim: law is well established that in the case of a contract for sale of unascertained goods the property does not pass to the purchaser unless there is unconditional appropriation of the goods in a deliverable state to the contract

anchor.surface_text: The law is well established that in the case of a contract for ,sale of unascertained goods the property does not pass to the purchaser unless there is unconditional appropriation, of the goods in a deliverable state to the contract.

holdings.text: the property in the rubber consignment passed to the appellant in the State of Bombay

anchor.surface_text: Applying this principle to the present case, we are of the opinion that the High Court rightly held, upon the facts found, that the property in the rubber consignment passed to the appellant in the State of Bombay.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bill of lading to order of sellers as consignors and consignees reserved right of disposal under S.25 Sale of Goods Act until endorsement and payment in Bombay; precedents (Shepherd v. Harrison, Gabarron v. Kreeft) confirm risk terms do not pass property if jus disponendi reserved

holdings.text: there is no warrant for this submission [property passed in Cochin] and the view taken by the High Court is correct

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no warrant for this submission and the view taken by the High Court is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agents accepted orders in Bombay; shipment under bill of lading to sellers' order constituted conditional appropriation only passing property on fulfillment in Bombay

holdings.text: The provisions of s. 10 a of the Act are satisfied in the present case and the purchases in question accordingly are liable to tax

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of s. 10 a  of the Act are satisfied in the present case and the purchases in question accordingly are liable to tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant is dealer under s.2(6); Cochin sellers are persons not registered dealers under Act; plain terms of s.10(a) levy purchase tax on such purchases

holdings.text: We are unable to accept the argument [that 'person' in s.10(a) means only dealer carrying business in Bombay not registered]; no reason for placing any limitation or qualification on the term person

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the argument put forward by Mr. Donde as correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of s.10(a) uses 'person' without qualification; nothing in context or s.2(6)/s.2(11) limits to local dealers; covers any non-registered person

holdings.text: That section plainly states that purchases made by a dealer from a person who is not a registered dealer will be subject to purchase tax. The appellant is a dealer and it has made the purchases in question from the sellers who are not registered dealers

anchor.surface_text: That section plainly states that purchases made by a dealer from a person who is not a registered dealer will be subject to purchase tax. The appellant is a dealer and it has made the purchases in question from the sellers who are not registered dealers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.10(a) text to undisputed facts of appellant's status and sellers' non-registration

holdings.text: We do not think there is any warrant in this argument [s.10(a) cannot apply to outside purchases as s.10-C applies]

anchor.surface_text: We do not think there is any warrant in this argument.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.10-C limited to notified goods despatched from outside and delivered for consumption, reproducing Expl. to Art.286(1)(a); distinct scope from general s.10(a)

holdings.text: It is manifest that the scope and ambit of these two sections [s.10(a) and s.10-C] are different

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the scope and ambit of these two sections are different.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.10(a) covers all purchases from non-reg dealers; s.10-C specific to certain outside goods notified for consumption/use, not overlapping with dealers' taxes under s.6

precedents.cited_proposition: the appropriation would not be such as to pass the property if it appears or can be inferred that there was no actual intention to pass it if the seller takes the bill of lading to his own order
precedents.cited_holding: the English cases... seem to show that the appropriation would not be such as to pass the property if it appears or can be inferred that there was no actual intention to pass it

anchor.surface_text: In Shepherd v. Harrison 1  the plaintiff in England sent an order to P and Co. at Pernambuco to buy companyton for the plaintiff. P and Co. bought companyton on account of the plaintiff and made out an invoice on account and risk of M s. John Shepherd Co.  1  1871 L.R.  V  H.L. 11 6. but the bills of lading were taken deliverable to P and Co.s order or assigns paying freight.

precedents.cited_proposition: property in the goods did not pass to the plaintiffs although they had retained the bill of lading because no property was intended to pass until the plaintiff had accepted the bills of exchange despite shipped on account and at the risk of the buyer
precedents.cited_holding: the property in the goods did not pass to the purchaser either in Pernambuco or in Liverpool

edges.explanation: The argument directly articulates the concept of reservation of right of disposal prima facie by bill of lading to seller or agent.
The argument on reserved right of disposal supports the holding that property passed in Bombay, implying disposal occurred there.
The argument that seller reserves right of disposal supports the holding rejecting property passage in Cochin.
The argument on seller's reservation of right of disposal via bill of lading addresses whether property passed in Cochin, as reservation implies it did not.
Both arguments rely on bill of lading reserving property despite risk; a5 general, a7 via precedent.
Argument on bill controlling possession supports property passing in Bombay.
Argument on bill reserving property supports no passage in Cochin.
Argument a5 on delivery to bailee and bill reserving property addresses issue of property passage in Cochin.
